commander.name: Major-General Richard Nugent O'Connor
commander.previous_service: Commander of 6th Infantry Division Egypt, prior service in Italian campaign WWI

command.headquarters_location: Baggush Box (Maaten Baggush), 35 miles east of Mersa Matruh, Egypt

variants.type: A13 Mk II Cruiser Mk IV

tanks.notes: 7th RTR with Matildas assigned as corps troops, 7th Armoured Division tanks integrated into total

units: 3rd Regiment RHA (Corps Troops, less two batteries) - 36 guns

top_3_infantry_weapons.notes: Combined from 7th Armoured (120 2-inch mortars estimated equivalent) and 4th Indian (96 Vickers MG)

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate - Pre-war garrison supply infrastructure. Main supply base at Mersa Matruh with forward dumps. Supply lines from Alexandria (150 miles east). Extended supply lines vulnerable to disruption. Heavy reliance on truck transport.

weather_environment.season_quarter: 1940-Q2 (April-June) - Late spring/Early summer in North Africa
weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal desert and rocky plateau (Egyptian-Libyan border region)

subordinate_units.notes: Mixed British-Indian composition: 40% British, 60% Indian personnel

composition.notes: First Matilda battalion in theater, spearhead for infantry operations

composition.unit: 3rd Regiment Royal Horse Artillery (less two batteries)

composition.notes: Heavy counter-battery and long-range fire support

composition.unit: Corps Signals (No.1 Company, 2nd New Zealand Divisional Signals + Royal Signals detachment)
composition.equipment: Wireless sets, cable laying equipment, telephone exchanges
composition.notes: New Zealand detachment arrived Baggush 9 June 1940, provided technical expertise for corps communications network
Mine laying, demolition, field fortifications including Baggush Box construction
Truck companies, supply depots, fuel distribution

tactical_doctrine.role: Corps-level command for mobile desert warfare - defense of Egypt against Italian invasion from Libya
special_capabilities: Extended desert operations with long supply lines
Mobile defense using armoured reconnaissance screen
Coordination of British and Commonwealth forces
tactical_innovations: Use of corps-level tank reserve (7th RTR Matildas) for breakthrough operations
Integrated signals network using New Zealand technical expertise
Forward headquarters at Baggush Box enabling rapid response
known_issues: Severe tank shortage across formation (234 vs 340+ authorized)
Extended supply lines from Alexandria (150 miles)
Limited medium artillery compared to Italian 10th Army
New formation still integrating command procedures
Water supply constraints in desert operations

historical_context.formation_history: Western Desert Force formed 17 June 1940 from headquarters of 6th Infantry Division. Created in response to Italian declaration of war (10 June 1940) to defend Egypt and Suez Canal. Predecessor to XIII Corps (redesignated 1 January 1941) and ultimately Eighth Army.
historical_context.operational_status: Defensive posture June 1940. First combat operations 11 June 1940 when 11th Hussars crossed into Libya. Conducting aggressive reconnaissance and border patrols awaiting Italian offensive. Preparing defensive positions at Mersa Matruh and forward screening positions.
quarter_events: 10 June 1940: Italy declares war on Britain and France
11 June 1940: First combat - 11th Hussars raid into Libya, 70 Italian POWs
17 June 1940: Western Desert Force officially formed under Major-General O'Connor
June 1940: Construction of Baggush Box headquarters and supply depot
June 1940: Integration of New Zealand signals detachment into corps communications
historical_context.commonwealth_forces: Corps includes British (7th Armoured Division) and Indian Army (4th Indian Division) formations. New Zealand signals detachment providing technical support for corps communications. Represents early example of British Commonwealth integrated command in WW2.
historical_context.strategic_context: Fall of France (June 1940) leaves Britain isolated. Western Desert Force faces Italian 10th Army in Libya (~250,000 men vs WDF's ~31,000). Egypt and Suez Canal vital to British Empire communications. WDF must defend with limited resources while reinforcements mobilize.

special_rules: Desert Navigation: No penalty for open terrain movement
Extended Supply Lines: -1 penalty to supply rolls beyond 150 miles from Alexandria
Matilda Breakthrough: 7th RTR provides infantry tank support capability
Commonwealth Cooperation: British-Indian integration provides tactical flexibility
Water Constraints: Desert operations limited by water availability (7 liters/man/day)

calculation_notes.personnel: Calculated from subordinate divisions (7th Armoured 10,000 + 4th Indian 15,000) plus estimated corps troops (5,500) and headquarters (500). Corps troops strength estimated from standard British artillery regiment establishments (~650 men) and engineer/signals units.
calculation_notes.tanks: Aggregated from 7th Armoured Division (228) plus 7th RTR corps troops (6 Matilda II). Total: 234 tanks.
calculation_notes.artillery: Aggregated from divisional assets (7th Armoured 180, 4th Indian 96) plus corps artillery (108 guns from 7 artillery regiments). Total: 384 guns.
calculation_notes.vehicles: Aggregated from subordinate divisions plus estimated 300 additional trucks for corps troops and headquarters.
calculation_notes.top_3_weapons: Combined infantry weapons from both divisions. Lee-Enfield rifles primary weapon across all units.

validation.data_quality_notes: TO&E primarily constructed by aggregating subordinate unit data (Tier 1 local sources) plus corps troops identified from web sources (Tier 2). No local documents available for June 1940 British Army Lists. Corps troops organization based on multiple corroborating web sources. Personnel estimates for corps units based on standard British establishments. Overall confidence reduced to 78% due to reliance on web sources for corps-level detail and lack of primary documents for 1940-Q2.
